data.title: Couples Expenses
data.subtitle: Split your common expenses
data.description: Individual project. My first TypeScript and Next.js app. Responsive design. In english. It's an app that helps you split your common expenses at the end of each month.

whatILearned.paragraph: It was fun to learn TypeScript and Next.js, I still have a way to go before mastering it.

data.title: Markdown Reminders
data.subtitle: A MERN TODO app using Markdown
data.description: Group project. Responsive design. In English.

whatILearned.paragraph: We made our first react-testing-library tests with this app. Very basic tests. We also made some simple integration tests on the backend.

data.title: Cats & Dogs
data.subtitle: a MERN Full-Stack Webshop
data.description: Group project in English with responsive design.

whatILearned.paragraph: We used a Husky pre-commit hook with linting and integration tests for this project. Which was a cool way to work on a group project.

data.title: Developing the Developer 2.0
data.subtitle: My updated portfolio page
data.description: Built with Create React App using my REST API for dynamic content. Styled with CSS modules and also used a bit of bootstrap because I was lazy :)

whatILearned.paragraph: It was fun to make my first front end for my new portfolio API. With this, I can update my portfolio very quickly.

data.title: Bj√∂rn's Portfolio API
data.subtitle: REST API and CMS for my Portfolio 2.0
data.description: This app lets me manage the content of my portfolio quickly and easily. It's a Express, MongoDB app with a simple Bootstrapped admin interface.

whatILearned.paragraph: I developed this app in order to separate the content from the frontend of my portfolio. This way I can quickly update my portfolio with content, as well as trying out different portfolio designs.
It's a Node/Express/MongoDB app using EJS templating with a very high level of complexity. Project images are uploaded to Cloudinary.
The architecture is heavily inspired from the Natours project in this Udemy course: https://www.udemy.com/course/nodejs-express-mongodb-bootcamp/

data.title: Natours
data.subtitle: Fullstack Node.JS App
data.description: Huge project from a Udemy course. Including maps, payments, photo uploads, and much more...

whatILearned.paragraph: Huge project from a Udemy course. Including maps, payments, photo uploads, and much more...
Made with Node.js/Express/MongoDB/pug/ JWT/Stripe/Cloudinary/SendGrid/mapbox and much more
I really recommend this course for people who wants to learn how to make fullstack apps: https://www.udemy.com/course/nodejs-express-mongodb-bootcamp/

data.title: MIB REST API
data.subtitle: My own CRUDable API for MIB Customer Data
data.description: Node.JS/MongoDB CRUDable REST API for my MIB Customer Data app.

whatILearned.paragraph: This project was inspired by the design of the Natours project. I wanted to make my own CRUDable REST API for my react frontend app MIB Customer Data.

data.title: ManCave
data.subtitle: PHP Fullstack Webshop Project
data.description: Group project. Fullstack project using MySQL/PHP/EJS. Responsive design.

whatILearned.paragraph: Made using vanilla PHP, a MySQL database and EJS templating.

The code design is object oriented with a MVC structure and using dependency injection. We have tried to write descriptive relatively short public methods in the classes that utilises helper methods to get the job done.

data.title: GitLab CI/CD Project
data.subtitle: Pipeline building a Docker image
data.description: In this project we used a GitLab pipeline that tested a Node.JS app and built it into a Docker image. I‚Äôm gonna add the repo soon.

whatILearned.paragraph: In this project we learned the basics of Docker, Eslint and Prettier.
We also learned the basics of writing both unit- and integration tests with Husky and Mocha. In the end, we only made a fake deploy of the app.

data.title: The Fakestore Creator
data.subtitle: Auto generate site from REST API
data.description: I only completed basic functionality for this project. Paste in a REST API with products and you'll get a visual representation.

whatILearned.paragraph: I wanted to experiment a little with generating visual representations from REST API. My plan was to let you customize how you could display the data.
We'll see if I'll make an improved version in the future...

data.title: Lego Fakestore API
data.subtitle: A REST API made by PHP
data.description: REST API with filter function. You can filter by category and limit how many results you want. Like this: https://legofakestore-api.herokuapp.com/v2/?category=technic&show=2

whatILearned.paragraph: REST API with filter function built by PHP. You can filter by category and limit how many results you want. Like this: https://legofakestore-api.herokuapp.com/v2/?category=technic&show=2

data.title: Bj√∂rn's Fakestore
data.subtitle: My first PHP app
data.description: Simple "fake store" generated from a REST API.

whatILearned.paragraph: My first PHP app. Simple "fake store" generated from an REST API provided to us.
Made using a theme from startbootstrap.com

data.title: Wack
data.subtitle: Slack clone fullstack project
data.description: Individual project. My first fullstack project. Made with Node/Express/MongoDB/Socket.IO/EJS.

whatILearned.paragraph: Individual project. My first fullstack project. Made with Node/Express/MongoDB/Socket.IO/EJS.
It took some time to learn how to use Socket.IO and websockets. And I could do with practicing it more.
After several projects built using Bootstrap I wanted to get back to basics and used vanilla CSS to style this one.

data.title: Yahtzee MongoDB Data
data.subtitle: A MongoDB database design
data.description: My first MongoDB database. Group project. Including queries.

whatILearned.paragraph: My first MongoDB database. Group project. Including queries.

data.title: Max Video DB
data.subtitle: A MySQL database design
data.description: My first MySQL database. Including views, stored procedures, sample data and statistics.

whatILearned.paragraph: My first MySQL database. Including views, stored procedures, sample data and statistics.

data.title: MIB Customer Data
data.subtitle: A customer data management app
data.description: Individual project. Slightly more advanced React app. Responsive design. In English.

whatILearned.paragraph: In this individual project I learned how to use the hook "useContext", as well as working with form validation and login functionality in a React app.
We made use of a RESTful CRUD API provided by our teacher.

data.title: EZORRO!
data.subtitle: STOCK MARKET HERO
data.description: Group project. My first React site. Responsive design. In English.

whatILearned.paragraph: We made this site with create-react-app and Bootstrap with a custom color palette. It is connected to a small read-only database on Firebase via an API.
We made a dynamic arrow icon with styled-components (and Font Awesome) that is used on the currency and markets detail pages.
With this site we have used Bootstraps responsive classes for the layout. A first for me.

data.title: Developing the Developer 1.0
data.subtitle: My first portfolio
data.description: My first portfolio site that was replaced a year later. No longer online, but you can check out the screenshots.

whatILearned.paragraph: I started the site by using Bootstrap 5 Alpha and customized the classes a bit as well as adding my own color palette. As you can see it's autumn themed.
But because the project required us to show we can use grid and flexbox I used that for the main layout of the page instead of bootstraps classes.
I used media queries and responsive images for the first time to make the site responsive.
Of course, I also had to use some Font Awesome icons.  I didn't use any JS on this project other than Bootstraps built-in JS.

data.title: ACME Events
data.subtitle: Site for entertainment events
data.description: Group project. An event page where you can CRUD events to Local Storage. Non-responsive design. In Swedish.

whatILearned.paragraph: For this group project we were asked to create functionality for "CRUDing" events to/from Local Storage (LS). We opted for translating all JS event-objects into JSON and saving them as one JSON object in LS each time any changes were made.
If you load the page without any events already in LS, our JS will create five "default events" and save them there.

data.title: Javascript Quiz
data.subtitle: Test your coding knowledge
data.description: Individual project. A quiz app that fetches its questions from a REST API. Semi-responsive design. In English.

whatILearned.paragraph: We were asked to make a quiz web app by fetching questions from a REST API.  This was interesting, cause I had never used an API before and also never used async JavaScript.
I chose to do this by making two HTML pages where the first is actually a form for choosing how many questions you want. The second HTML page is kind of a SPA (single-page application).
If you pay attention, you might notice that there is a "fetching questions" text displayed for a fraction of a second before the "start quiz" button appears.

data.title: Yahtzee Game
data.subtitle: Play the classic dice game on the web
data.description: Group project. Uses javascript to simulate dice throws. My first web project. Only basic features completed. Non-responsive design.

whatILearned.paragraph: For our first school project we were asked to make a Yahtzee game from scratch using JavaScript.
We were introduced to DOM manipulation, object-oriented coding as well as basic HTML and CSS during our development of the site.
Though we wanted to do more with this site, we didn't find the time to complete the full functionality that we had intended. In order to meet the deadline, we opted for a very simple final product.
Actually not bad for four guys completely new to web development to throw together in two weeks!

data.title: Dice Game
data.subtitle: A simple Java game
data.description: One of the few things I have written in Java. Enable "Interactive" to try the game out. In English.

whatILearned.paragraph: One of the few things I have written in Java. Enable "Interactive" to try the game out. In English.
